dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fade up on Ripley, as in the final scene of the film, sitting, desolate in a ship's cabin. The camera rotates around his face, which begins in light and ends in darkne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could just go back. If I could rub everything out. Starting with myself. Starting with borrowing a jacket. EXT. CENTRAL PARK WEST TERRACE. EARLY EVENING. Ripley is at the piano, accompanying FRAN, a young sopran CREDITS begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, such fleeting paradise such innocent delight to love, be loved, a lullabye, then silence. The song finishes. Applause. They're the entertainment cocktail party to celebrate a silver wedding anniversary. Some partygoers congratulate Fran on her performance. A distinguished looking man, pushing his wife in a wheelcha approaches Ripley, offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most enjoyable. Herbert Greenleaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Ripley. Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at Ripley's borrowed jacket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you were at Princeton. Then you'll most likely know our son, Dick. Dickie Greenleaf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't help noticing your jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class of '56?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Dickie? INT. ELEVATOR OPENING OUT INTO LOBBY. EARLY EVENING. Fran, Ripley, Mr and Mrs Greenleaf and others emerge from elevator. Emily talks to Fran, Herbert to Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fran)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you'll come and see us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Dickie's idea of music is Jazz. He has a saxophone.  To my ear Jazz is just noise, just an insolent noise. EXT. CENTRAL PARK WEST. EARLY EVENING. Ripley shakes hands with Herbert Greenleaf as he gets int his Rolls Royce. They are making an appointment. Ripley crosses the street to Fran, pecks her cheek. She hands hi his share of their fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta run. I'm so late. (he hands Fran's boyfriend the jacket he's been wearing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Thanks for filling in for me. From Greenleaf's point of view he sees a couple embracing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling couple, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  An exceptional young man. From another vantage point Ripley hurries on as Fran gets into her boyfriend's car. A piano quartet starts up. EXT. THEATER. EVENING. Ripley runs past the droves of arriving concert-goers and heads for the theater. Music continues. INT. MEN'S ROOM, THEATER. NIGHT. The interval: A thick mass of men in tuxedoes grooming themselves at the basins. Ripley turns on faucets, offers towels, brushes off dandruff. Men talk over, round, and through him.  Put coins in a bowl.

dialogues.speaker: INT. A BOX AT THE THEATER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The concert continues. Ripley peers through the curtain a the performances.  A haughty woman in the box turns round he closes the curtain. INT. BACKSTAGE. 1:30 A.M. An empty auditorium. Ripley plays Bach in the blue ghostlight.  A caretaker emerges from his rounds, flips o the house lights.  Ripley jerks up from his playing, wave apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry.  I know.  Sorry. EXT. GREENLEAF SHIPYARDS, BROOKLYN. DAY. Greenleaf and Ripley walk through one of the drydocks.  A huge void in the shape of a boat, swarming with workers preparing the shell of a new liner.  If Central Park is w the money is spent, this is clearly where it's made.  And lot of it. Workers nod deferentially to the man with his over the buildings behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mongibello. Tiny place. South of Naples. Marge, his uh, the young lade is supposedly writing some kind of book. God knows what he does. By all accounts they spend the whole time on the beach. Or his sailboat. That's my son's talent, spending his allowance. Ripley, in his green corduroy jacket the very model of a sober young man, listens attentively. HERBERT GREENLEAF (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you ever conceive of going to Italy, Tom, persuade my son to come home? (Ripley looks doubtful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd pay you.  I'd pay you 1000 dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to go to Europe, sir, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now you can go for a reason. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT, NEW YORK. DAY. A vinyl RECORD revolves in close up. An exuberant and mysterious VOICE is scat singing. Wild. Then the sound sl into a raucous big band jazz number: Dizzy Gillespie's < Champ. A HAND ejects the record. When the camera find man's face it is BLINDFOLDED. He's hot. He's wearing an undershirt. He's trying to identify the recording.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Count Basie? Duke Ellington. I don't know. Count Basie. The man pulls of the blindfold, examines the record cover the disc he's been trying to learn, needs to put on glass to do so, is irritated by his mistake. He ejects the reco A pile of other jazz records are strewn across a cluttere table which includes classical sheet music and a paper keyboard. One hand idly mimes at the keys. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. DAY. Another song for Ripley to identify is on the gramophone. Chet Baker's My Funny Valentine. Signs everywhere packing. A suitcase. Books about Italy. Ripley paces in BASEMENT room, which is bathroom, kitchen, living room an bedroom all in one. Tiny, tidy, squalid and sad. The win give onto bars and a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even know if this is a man or a woman. There's a violent row going on in the room above his head flinches. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. DAY. Ripley, shining his shoes, packing almost done, is testin himself on another piece of music. Free jazz saxophone: Charlie Parker's Koko. He listens hard, recognize track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Charlie Parker. Bird. He skips over to the gramophone, checks the record. He's right, he smiles. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. DAY. Ripley studies an old photograph of Dickie Greenleaf in a Princeton Yearbook. He shoves the book in a bag, picks up his suitcase and takes a last look around the dingy apart before closing the door behind him. EXT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. DAY. Ripley hauls his luggage up the stairs and into the sunli He is met at the top of the stairs by Mr Greenleaf's chauffeur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  I'll take that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding towards the apartment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thousand bucks should come in handy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interupts Ripley, who is about to open the car door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he holds open the door for Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. (Ripley laughs excitedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have a great trip.  Mr Greenleaf is personal friends with the Cunard people. INT. HERBERT GREENLEAF'S CAR. DAY. Ripley luxuriates in the back of the Greenleaf limousine. opens up an envelope he's carrying with Greenleaf station Inside a First Class Cunard Ticket, some traveler's check and dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you. The Greenleaf name opens a lot of doors. EXT. QUEEN MARY, MANHATTAN SKYLINE. DAY. The liner leaves New York en route to Italy. END CREDITS INT. NAPLES HARBOR, CUSTOMS & IMMIGRATION HALL. DAY. ITALY. Brilliant sunshine. The Queen Mary has just docked Passengers can be seen disembarking through the huge wind Coming from the First Class gangways they are greeted, escorted, fussed over into the hall. Their bags have bee unloaded ahead of them, and are now being sorted in the h under the initials of their owners. STANDS WITH THE LETT OF THE ALPHABET CHALKED ON THEM are dotted about, and tru and suitcases of all shapes and sizes form small hills ar them. Ripley enters and an Italian Porter approaches, wan his name. Ripley. Ripley. Ripley! he repeats in t and joins the crowd around the letter R. A striking youn woman (MEREDITH) is nearby. She notices him. Ripley proceeds to the Customs area, where he's held in a line as a large suitcase is opened and searched. Meredith catches up with him. Her luggage a mountain next to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just - you are American, aren't you? - no, I just, I have so much luggage, and you're so, uh, streamlined. It's humiliating. Ripley shrugs.  Now they're opening a second case of the passenger ahead.  Hard not to converse. MEREDITH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Meredith, by the way. Meredith Randall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie, Dickie Greenleaf. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. They are passed through immigration, head down the long stairs towards the street.  Meredith catches up with Ripl MEREDITH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the Shipping Greenleaf's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying not to be. Trying to jump ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now, did they put your suitcase in the wrong pile? It's just - upstairs - weren't you under the R stand? I thought I saw you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father wants me in New York. He builds boats. I'd rather sail them.  I travel under my mother's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily. (Meredith's bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funny thing is, I'm not Randall either. I'm Logue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, recognizing the name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in the...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in the Textile Logues. Trying to shrug off the dress. I travel under my mother's name, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. They've arrived at a crossroads on the stairs - graphic s explain the choices: one way for Buses, Taxis and exits - other for Trains: ROMA, VENEZIA, MILANO.  They're going i different directions. MEREDITH (cont'd) (offering her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - partners in disguise. (looks at the signs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. EXT. COASTAL ROAD FROM NAPLES. LATE AFTERNOON. A BUS rolls around a coastal road cut into the side of a cliff, mountain above, blue sea below. INT. BUS. LATE AFTERNOON. Ripley sits surrounded by teeming life. The bus slows at new town. People get off. INT/EXTERIOR. BUS ARRIVES MONGIBELLO. LATE DAY. Later, the day ending. Ripley looks out as they continue their journey. Arriving at a small fishing port they wind down through a square, passing the local church. EXT. MONGIBELLO, FISHERMAN'S WHARF. LATE DAY. And then the bus is in the heart of a wharf. On one side there's evidence of the fisherman's life, nets, old men working. Opposite there's a tiny cafe spilling out onto t street, young guys hang out, play table football, lounge their Vespas. The Driver chants -

dialogues.speaker: MONGIBELLO
dialogues.text: Ripley gets out, lugging his cases, as the bus continues its way. He looks around him. He feels completely foreign EXT. MIRAMARE HOTEL/BOAT AT SEA. MORNING. A SAILBOAT has slid into his view, now drops anchor, drop the sail.  A couple dive off and swim towards shore. ALL OF THIS IS FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF RIPLEY, who's watching the events through binoculars from his tiny balc in the Miramare Hotel. An Italian Vocabulary Book is perc on his knees and, during this, he continues his study, mouthing the Italian words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at a long, lean girl about to dive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La fidanzata a una faccia.  The fiancГ€e has a face.  La fidanzata e Marge. Her partner, DICKIE GREENLEAF, dives too. They're brown, beautiful, perfect. Ripley notices the name of the boat: "BIRD". RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Questo e la mia faccia..... The golden couple emerge from the sea. Dickie shakes off water, grins. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my face. He double-checks himself with the vocabulary book. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Questa...e la mia faccia. Questa e la faccia di Dickie. EXT. MONGIBELLO. DAY. Ripley emerges from one of the beach cabins, and stands o the edge of the sand on a wooden walkway. He's wearing A LIME-GREEN BATHING SUIT. He loathes beaches. A couple of turn laconically and watch him. Ripley puts on his shoes and scurries to the sea. He feel ridiculous, his skin alabaster against the brown bodies. Finally, the shame is too great and he pulls off his shoe and dashes to the water, where he luxuriates in the cooln of it before wading out of the sea, and walking straight to Dickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie Greenleaf? Dickie squints at Ripley, who holds his shoes, lamely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Tom. Tom Ripley. We were at Princeton together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (he sits up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did we know each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I knew you, so I suppose you must have known me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princeton is like a fog, America's like a fog. (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Marge Sherwood. Tom - sorry, what was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley. Hullo. How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in Mongi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing much. Passing through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finds this idea absurd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing through! You're so white. Did you ever see a guy so white, Marge?  Gray, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just an undercoat. (Marge laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a primer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny. He shares some intimacy with Marge, makes her laugh.  Rip stands as they wrestle around him. Marge looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should come and have lunch with us, before you go - Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And be careful in the sun. Your gray's in danger of turning a little pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Well, a coincidence. EXT. MONGIBELLO. EARLY MORNING. ANOTHER DAY.  Church Bells ringing. Dickie, dressed in shorts, comes bumping up the cobbled path towards the squ on his MOTORSCOOTER. He stops by a steep flight of steps. RIPLEY, a book in hand, unseen, walking up a hill, catche all this and, intrigued, watches as a young Italian beaut SILVANA, has a spikey, flirtatious exchange with Dickie, climbs on the scooter, behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, today you're looking for me.  And where have you been the rest of the week? Pig.  With your American girl?  I hate you, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you. And RIPLEY watches them as they rattle down the hill towa the sea. EXT. MARGE'S HOUSE. AFTERNOON. Dickie appears in Marge's garden, the sea behind his head Marge is sitting at her outside table surrounded by some the remnants of lunch.  Dickie's sheepish, showered, late

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry, sorry. I know, I'm late, I'm a swine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you forget where I live? It's four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just woke up.  I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just woke up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fausto and I - we took the boat out, we were fishing, and then it was dawn and we'd caught absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we ate everything without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Tom Ripley's here. As Ripley appears with the tray to collect more dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Oh, Tom, hello, how are you? We thought you'd disappeared. We were going to send out a search party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom was telling me about his trip over. Made me laugh so much I got a nosebleed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Marge flicks him with a napkin. They start to wrestle, excluding Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm intruding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you mix a martini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going inside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it. I make a fabulous martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody should have one talent. (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forging signatures. Telling lies. Impersonating practically anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying this banter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's three. Nobody should have more than one talent. Okay, do an impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?  Okay.  Wait a minute.  Talent - (his voice ages, his face changes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only talent my son has is for cashing his allowance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absolutely thrown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to sail, believe me, I love to sail! Instead I make boats and other people sail them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredibly impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! It's too much!  You're making all the hairs on my neck stand up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relishing it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz, let's face it, it's just an insolent noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like he's here. Horrible. Like the old bastard is here right now!  That's brilliant!  How do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met him in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge! You've got to hear this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning with the drinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet my father, Herbert Richard Greenleaf 1st.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you, Dickie's made a fine catch. I know Emily thinks so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncanny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you ever conceive of going there, Tom, and bringing him back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd pay you. If you would go to Italy and persuade my son to come home. I'd pay you $1000. INT/EXT. MONGIBELLO CHURCH AND SQUARE. DUSK. A christening is over and now the whole village is pourin out of Church for the Passeggiata in Sunday best. in arm parade. Boys arm in arm evaluate. New babies are compared and fussed over. Old people smoke, talk, shrug. Dickie is walking with Ripley, seething about his father' scheming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never going back. To actually hire somebody to come all the way here to drag me back home - got to be insane, hasn't he? SILVANA comes out of church arm in arm with a man, her fiancee, as part of a foursome which includes Dickie's pa FAUSTO. Silvana's eyes flick towards Dickie, otherwise there's no acknowledgement as they all greet each other. Dickie introduces Tom, then they move on. DICKIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never going back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think your mother, her illness -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got nothing to do with my mother! She's had leukemia for - ! This is what makes me boil about him! HE wants me back! - it's got nothing to do with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Dickie, I'm just telling you what I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back!  Go back to New York or call him if you can find a telephone that works, and tell him wild horses wouldn't drag me back to him or his shipyard. EXT. DICKIE'S HOUSE, MONGIBELLO. AFTERNOON. Ripley appears, with his meagre luggage at Dickie's front door. He's carrying his tote bag under his arm, the botto which seems to be unstitched and held together only by hi fingers. Marge is on the terrace, she looks down to see T talking with Dickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, Ripley's saying goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you speak to my father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right about the telephones. There are no lines, there's some problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming out of the front door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Tom. You're off? What are your plans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back, I suppose, slowly as I can. He goes to shake her hand and as he releases the tote bag seam splits and records spill to the ground, scattering. bends down, starts gathering them up. Marge helps. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, damn, sorry, this bag's - Dickie's delighted when he sees the Jazz titles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like jazz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering up the records)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up a Chet Baker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the best. Marge says she likes jazz, but she things Glenn Miller is jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird. That's jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird! Ask me the name of my sailboat -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. What's the name of your sailboat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is ridiculous. Boats are female, everyone knows you can't call a boat after a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a man, he's a god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we're going to Naples. There's a club, it's not a club, it's a cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's vile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's vile. Don't worry, you don't have to come. (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great. You're going to love it. INT. JAZZ CLUB, NAPLES. NIGHT. A cavern blue with smoke. A surprisingly good QUINTET bla out their version of MOANIN'. Dickie and Ripley ar make their way to a table where Fausto is sitting with friends. It's too noisy for conversation, but Dickie shou introductions and they shake Ripley's hand. Dickie is instantly absorbed in the music, Ripley absorbed in Dicki An attractive Italian Girl, DAHLIA, comes over, kisses Dickie, pulls off his hat, puts it on, there's no room fo her to sit, so she sits on Dickie's lap, smoking his cigarette. Dickie raises his eyebrow at Tom, but it's clearly no hardship. Then the band strikes up the intro t vuo' fa' L'Americano - a hit which reflects the curre for all things American - and Fausto pulls a protesting D up onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (improvising in Italian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen. Dickie Greenleaf, all the way from America... etc. Fausto starts to sing. Dickie joins in the chorus. Everyb claps. Dickie talks off-mic to Fausto. FAUSTO (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a big round of applause for a new friend from New York - Tom Ripley! Ripley's mortified, but Dickie jumps off the stage and pu him up. The song continues and now, at the chorus, it's Dickie and Ripley who have to sing. Ripley, of course, ca sing well, if not confident in this arena. Soon the audie is clapping, standing on tables, dancing, Dahlia prominen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have bumped into an old friend from Princeton - a fellow named Tom Ripley. He says he's going to haunt me until I agree to come back to New York with him... INT. DICKIE'S HOUSE. NOON. Dickie, in his new dressing gown, is sitting at the table typing. Ripley's head emerges from behind the couch on wh he has been enjoying a blissful sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? (puts on his glasses and checks his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God!  Do you always type your letters? (points at the letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should be two Ts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't write and I can't spell.  That's the privilege of a first-class education. You're upstairs at the back. I think Ermelinda made the bed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so good of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say it again. Now you're a Double Agent and we're going to string my Dad alone, I was thinking we might buy a little car with the expense money he's sending you. What do you think, Marge...a little Cinquecento with my Dad's money? Marge has appeared, carrying Camparis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie, you can't even drive a car!  No, what we need urgently is an icebox. What do you think, Tom? Agree with me and I'll be your friend for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I absolutely agree with Marge. INT. DICKIE'S HOUSE, UPSTAIRS. DAY. Ripley locates his room, puts down his luggage in what is comfortable and simple room, then heads back downstairs o to be tempted by the open door of Dickie's bedroom. INT. DICKIE'S BEDROOM. DAY. Ripley explores the casual elegance of Dickie's bedroom - Louis Vuitton chest, the closet's open door spilling out shirts, ties. On the dressing table there are toiletries, cufflinks scattered, a silk tie.  Ripley picks up the tie walks towards the open window below which is a terrace wh lunch is being laid. Marge and Dickie are chatting. Shred conversation float up to Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll just be for a little while.  He can be... he makes me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd say if you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, you like everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll go to your place and you can move in with Tom. Above them, Ripley repeats these phrases, carefully, test the cadences, <i>No, I like him. Marge, you like everybod until he's as accurate as a taperecorder. EXT. TERRACE OF DICKIE'S HOUSE. DAY. Ermelinda is clearing away lunch. Ripley is changed and sitting at the table with Marge while Dickie works on the coffee. Ripley watches him, studying everything: the way uses the expresso machine, the way he wears no socks, his pants, his rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know why Miss Sherwood always shows up for breakfast.  It's not love it's the coffee machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the one task Dickie can do on his own - make coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh darling - is that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's for Tom as he didn't complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Dickie hands him his cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ring's so great. The green one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, I love you! (to Dickie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See! (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought it for him, for his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's superb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to promise, capital P, never to take it off - otherwise I'd give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flicking a crumb at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard! (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it great, Tom? I found it in Naples.  I bargained for about two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it wasn't cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to find a birthday present for Frances. Perhaps you can help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fiancГ€e.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dark horse, Ripley. Engaged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God - I can just imagine - if only Dickie would settle down... doesn't every parent deserve a grandchild? Never! I swear on your ring, Marge. I am never going back. EXT. BIRD SAILBOAT. DAY. The Bird is sailing off the coast of Mongibello. There's manoeuvre going on with the sail. Captain Dickie supervi his crew of Marge and a painfully awkward anxious-to-plea Ripley. Dickie goes over to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing this wrong, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing great. We'll make a sailor of you yet. You're doing really well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dubious but special honor, Tom - crewing Dickie's boat.  Alright, bar's open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes please! She heads for the cabin. Dickie settles down beside Riple

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we sail to Venice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  I love Venice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go to Venice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See Venice and die, isn't that right? Or is it Rome? You do something and die, don't you?  Okay, Venice is on the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ski? (Ripley frowns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me - you're a lost cause! That's the next thing to deal with. We're planning to go to Cortina at Christmas. Excellent skiing. Excellent. (as Marge reappears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge - Ripley can't ski.  We'll have to teach him that, too. Have you ever known such low class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Tom. Good thing we're not getting married. We might have to invite him on our honeymoon. EXT. MONGIBELLO. LATE DAY. Marge and Ripley are on a shopping expedition. They walk the hill towards the grocery shop, next to the bar in the little square. Ripley has asked Marge how she and Dickie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I hated New York - that Park Avenue crowd - so I fled to Paris to work on my book, and I was always going to this cafe with Jean-Jacques, and Dickie used to play his saxophone outside and I would see him and he would see me, and he would play My Funny Valentine. It was only later that I realised he only knows about six songs. They've arrived at the Grocery Store. Alessandra, the wom who owns the store greets them. Silvana, who's her daugh is also there, and less comfortable. She waits for Marge' order. MARGE (cont'd) (to Silvana, in Italian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buono Sera, Silvana. Por favore: arance e pane, e del prosciutto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E fichi? Come sempre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si. Come sempre. Grazie. Silvana goes inside for the meat and bread. Marge frowns. MARGE (cont'd) (back to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, then one day, we go in, I see Dickie, he starts playing My Funny Valentine, and then all of a sudden he just walks into the cafe, right in front of Jean-Jacques, and grabs me! Now I had never spoken to him in my life - he said I'm going to Italy, tomorrow, and I want you to come with me. So I did. At the edge of the square there's A BOCCE AREA, where men throw metal balls along a track, aiming to get closest to small cue. Dickie is there, playing intensely with Fausto two other guys, one of whom we've seen before with Silvan Ripley and Marge loop back towards home, taking in the Bo en route. Dickie waves. They wave back. Marge calls to hi MARGE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not at my place by 7.00, Tom and I are running off together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. EXT. MARGE'S HOUSE. EARLY EVENING. Dickie and Ripley are leaving.  They're fooling around. Dickie jumps on Ripley's shoulders. Marge watches from th top of the garden. EXT. MONGIBELLO SQUARE. EARLY EVENING. Dickie and Ripley, still horsing about, pass Silvana's grocery store.  Dickie dismounts, goes over to Silvana, w tense, a little troubled. They huddle, Ripley isolated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get my message?  I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you too...Smile for me. And Dickie's already gone, back to Ripley feinting to box then dancing, satyr-like, down the hill. EXT. COASTAL ROAD TO NAPLES. EVENING. Dickie and Ripley on the Vespa. There's a steep incline w the road winds down towards Naples and, as the Vespa gain speed, Ripley is happy to cling to Dickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking my ribs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking my ribs! INT. JAZZ CLUB, NAPLES. NIGHT. Ripley's really singing, carrying the burden of My Fun Valentine in a flawless imitation of Chet Baker. Dick playing some sax. After a verse, there's spontaneous applause. Dickie, impressed beams at Ripley. INT. DICKIE'S HOUSE. NIGHT. A NEW ICEBOX, incongruous in pride of place in the living room, casts its glow on a delighted Dickie as he pulls ou couple of beers, handing one to Ripley who is paging thro his copy of the Collected Works of Shakespeare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could fuck this icebox I love it so much. (considering Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you actually doing in New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I played piano in a few places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one job, you told me a lot of jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few places - that's a few jobs. Anyway, I don't want to think about New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mysterious Mr Ripley. Marge and I spend hours speculating. (drinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold beer. Thank you Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copy out from here... He hands the book to Dickie, pointing out the lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring to write on the back of a postcard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the fact you brought Shakespeare with you and no clothes.  Ermelinda says you wash the same shirt out every night. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I've got more than one shirt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can do that stuff for you. Anyway, just wear some of my things, wear anything you want, most of it's ancient. (he's finished writing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now your signature. (watching him write)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not "Dickie". Your signature. Dickie writes his signature at the bottom of the postcard Ripley studies the writing, takes off his glasses to clea them. Dickie looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without the glasses you're not even ugly. (takes them, tries them on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need them because I never read. How do I look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Clark Kent. (takes them back, puts them on beaming at Dickie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Superman. Dickie cuffs him.  Ripley looks down at the postcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I write like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty vile. See this: The S and the T, do you see? - fine, vulnerable - that's pain, that's secret pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be a deep secret, cause I don't know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your handwriting - nothing more naked. See - nothing's quite touching the line - that's vanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flattered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we certainly know that's true. INT. DICKIE'S BATHROOM. NIGHT. Dickie's in the bath. Ripley, dressed, sits on the stool to the bath. They're in the middle of playing chess, the board propped on the bath tray. Ripley puts his hand in t water, checking the temperature. He turns on the faucet f burst of hot. Ripley is absurdly happy. He pours some win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no brothers, no sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: me neither. Nor does Marge. All only children - what does that mean? He looks at Ripley who looks at him, a little too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Means we never shared a bath. I'm cold. Can I get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean with you in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you get in. I'm like a prune anyway. He gets out, walks past Ripley, who doesn't turn around. Dickie's reflected in the mirror. Ripley looks, then Dick turns, holds his look momentarily before flicking him wit his towel. INT/EXT. AMERICAN EXPRESS OFFICE, NAPLES. DAY. An OFFICIAL is studying Dickie's passport photograph. It' not a recent picture. The official looks suspicious. Dick is used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is me. It's an old picture. (sighs at Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time - 'is it you?  Doesn't look like you'. He's signing for his allowance. He has a smart document c with his initials prominently embossed.  Ripley watches h sign and collect a large wad of notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letters - Greenleaf, and for Ripley. Ripley collects and studies his mail. As they walk outsid holds up one letter to Dickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fran. (anticipating her letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you, where are you coming home? Stop telling me what a great time you're having, how you love Dickie... and Marge and... (the next letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this one, I think, is your dad... INT. TRAIN TO ROME. DAY. Ripley sits reading the LETTER from Herbert Greenleaf.  H frowns, stops reading, looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting impatient. He wants me to reassure him you'll be home by Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to get a new jacket. Really. You must be sick of the same clothes. I'm sick of seeing you in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I can't keep spending your father's money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love how responsible you are. My Dad should make you Chief Accountant or something.  Let me buy you a jacket. There's a great place when we get to Rome, Batistoni. Ripley loves this idea and mouths the word, "Batistoni". DICKIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andiamo a Roma.  We're taking Tom to Roma! EXT. ARCARI'S CAFE, PIAZZA NAVONA, ROME. DAY. Ripley and Dickie sit outside at a Cafe in the Piazza Nav Very smart, very sophisticated, very young crowd.  There already several empty coffee cups and a half empty bottle Frascati.  Ripley has his guide book out and is incredibl impatient. Dickie, meanwhile, has stretched out for the duration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we find a carozza for the Forum, or can we hire any of them - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just there's so much to do in a single day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax. The most important question is where to eat. I hope Freddie made a reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie Miles.  You know - he's organizing the Cortina skiing trip. Ripley hates the idea of having this special day invaded. horn makes him look up as FREDDIE MILES illegally parks h open top sports car opposite the cafe, sees Dickie and bustles over.  He's a heavy-set American with a reddish crewcut. Ripley finds him disgusting to look at. Dickie i delighted. DICKIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederico!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao bello. (noticing a beautiful woman in an open-topped car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to fuck every woman you see.  Just once. They kiss cheeks, continental-style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Tom Ripley. Freddie Miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if I'm late, think what her husband's saying! He fills Dickie's glass with wine and drinks it standing FREDDIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's go. I got us a table outside at Fabrizio's. And Dickie's up, leaving Ripley to pick up all the tiny checks to work out the bill and pay it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you - I am so cabin-crazy with Mongi. Freddie and Dickie link arms Italian-style and cross the street to Freddie's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I was there. (looks back to see Ripley struggling to settle the check)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy!  It's S.R.O.  Two seater. Standing Room Only.  Chop, chop, Tommy! Ripley, abandoned, goes over. There's no room in the car. has to crouch in the rear. FREDDIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to sit between us. But don't put your shoes on the seat, know what I mean, put them one on top of the other.  Okay? INT. A JAZZ RECORD STORE. LATE AFTERNOON. This record store is hidden away down a cobbled alley, an stuffed with the trendiest Romans, all of whom rifle the stacks under a fog of cigarette smoke.  There are two LISTENING BOOTHS, one of which has Freddie and Dickie cra into it, sharing a set of headphones.  Ripley stands outs the booth, holding both of their jackets like a manservan while inside and behind the glass doors they chat animate He looks longingly at the street, where the light is fadi Dickie catches his hangdog expression and pushes open the accordion doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Tom, we've got to go to a club and meet some friends of Freddie's. The best thing is - if you want to be a tourist - grab a cab and we can meet up at the railway station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absolutely crestfallen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What club?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie's arranged it with some of the skiing crowd. Come if you want but I thought you wanted to see the Forum...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. And then maybe get the jacket and what have you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from inside the booth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick - you've got to hear this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oblivious to Ripley's pain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, just take one of mine when we get back. Don't worry about it.  I did the Forum with Marge and, frankly, once is enough in anyone's life. Ripley hands him the coats, turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao.  Have fun. Ripley heads for the door, then comes back, raps on the booth.  Dickie pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said to make sure you didn't miss the train. It leaves at eight. EXT. THE CAPITOL. LATE AFTERNOON. Ripley hikes up Michelangelo's Arcoeli Steps. Then he's looking down from the Campodoglio at the Forum below. The he's walking by the oversized fragments of the Colossus. is the real Ripley, the lover of beauty, inspired by art, antiquity. He's awed. He's cold. He so much wishes he wer alone. INT. ROME RAILWAY STATION. NIGHT. It's past eight, Ripley stands, one foot on the guard ste the Naples train, waiting forlornly for Dickie, then givi up as the train pulls away. He pulls the door to his compartment closed, and sits inside the train alone. INT. DICKIE'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. There's music playing, Bing Crosby's "May I". Very loud. Ripley dances to the mirror, SPECTACLES ABANDONED and DRE AS DICKIE IN HIS TUXEDO, MINUS TROUSERS. He adjusts his h catches one of Dickie's expressions.  There are clothes abandoned everywhere.  He's been having a big dressing-up session. He sings along with Bing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Ripley turns, horrified, to see Dickie standing in the doorway.  The music thumps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - just amusing myself.  Sorry, Dickie. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think you were coming back. Dickie turns off the record player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd get out of my clothes. Ripley starts undressing, his fingers clumsy with mortification and shock.  Dickie looks at his feet, shake his head. DICKIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoes too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lame, ashamed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I could pick out a jacket and I just... Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get undressed in your own room, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd missed the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie drove me back in his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Freddie here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just fooling around. Don't say anything. Sorry. Dickie lets him leave and then sits amongst the debris of dressing-up session, not amused. EXT. DICKIE'S TERRACE. DAY. Ripley comes down, apprehensive, to find Marge and Dickie Freddie having a jolly breakfast on the terrace. Dickie l perfectly happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Tom.  Come join us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want this job of yours, Tommy. I was just saying - You live in Italy, sleep in Dickie's house, eat Dickie's food, wear his clothes, and his father picks up the tab. If you get bored, let me know, I'll do it! EXT. THE OCEAN, ABOARD THE BIRD. DAY. The boat is drifting.  Freddie and Dickie and Marge are swimming, then Marge climbs back onto the boat, where Rip is sitting alone, reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really should go in, it's marvellous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. She approaches him, conscious of his isolation. She's in red bikini, and she towels herself dry as they speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. They watch Dickie and Freddie fooling around in the water

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing with Dickie - it's like the sun shines on you and it's glorious, then he forgets you and it's very very cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm learning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not even aware of it. When you've got his attention you feel like you're the only person in the world. That's why everybody loves him. Other times... There's a yell from Dickie as Freddie wrestles with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing and choking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drowning me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always the same whenever someone new comes into his life - Freddie, Fausto, Peter Smith-Kingsley - he's wonderful - did you meet him, he's a musician? - ... and especially you, of course... and that's only the boys. They watch as Freddie pushes Dickie under the surface. MARGE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, why is it when men play they always play at killing each other...? I'm sorry about Cortina by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Cortina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Dick say? - he talked to Freddie... apparently it's not going to work out - (Ripley's devastated, Marge notices, can't look at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie says there aren't enough rooms. EXT. OCEAN, ABOARD THE BIRD. DUSK. LATER and now the boat is sailing again. Ripley is sittin his spot. Dickie and Freddie are at the tiller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Frederico, do you really have to go back?  At least stick around for the Festival of the Madonna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Come back with me to Rome. There's this great new club.  Have some drinks, lotta ladies... Marge, still in her bikini, disappears into the cabin. Di makes a face at Freddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you can steer this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just point her at Capri and avoid the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge-maintenance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, aye. Dickie heads towards the cabin. Freddie takes over the tiller. There's a breeze and the sailboat cuts through th water. From where Ripley sits he can see Capri in the distance, he can also look down into the cabin, its porthole offeri him a restricted view.  He looks down and there's a flash flesh, then nothing.  Then as the boat swings with the wa he glimpses the bikini top flung over a chair, and then Marge's bare foot kicking out rhythmically, the red-paint toes straining.  Ripley's mesmerized, aroused, and absolu betrayed. FREDDIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy - How's the peeping? Come on Tommy, you were looking.  Tommy Tommy Tommy. Shamed, Ripley looks away. He stares at the water, partin before the boat, its turmoil reflecting his. EXT. DICKIE'S MOORING. DAY. The Bird returns to the mooring by Dickie's House.  Dicki ever Captain of the Ship, clambering around, shouting instructions, with Ripley, Marge and Freddie as crew.  Ri looks back at shore. Silvana stands watching, staring. Dickie notices her too. EXT. MONGIBELLO SLIPWAY. LATE DAY. A WOMAN'S HEAD suddenly breaks the surface of the water. It's a statue of the Virgin Mary, life size, adorned with flowers and a lace veil.  As she is revealed, wooden, staring, four men emerge, lifting the statue on a palette wading towards the shore, the Madonna aloft on their shoulders. The whole town of Mongibello is in attendance for this An Festival of the Madonna del Mare, either standing in thei fishing boats, or on shore and flanking the Parish Priest altar boys and incense. RIPLEY, DICKIE and MARGE watch fr Dickie's terrace. There are hymns and, as the statue is carried to the shore, the men's heads barely above the wa the congregation applauds at the illusion that the Madonn walking on water. Suddenly ANOTHER HEAD appears on the surface of the water about fifty yards from the statue. There's a scream from among the crowd as someone notices the body. It's SILVANA One of the MEN carrying the statue turns first towards th direction of the scream and then towards the floating cor It's Silvana's fiancee, and in a second he has let go of palette, CAUSING IT TO TOPPLE, and - in absolute grief - wades, swims, splashes towards the body. PANDEMONIUM in the crowd, which breaks up, with other peo splashing, fully clothed, into the water. From the terrac Ripley turns and looks at Dickie, catching his eye. EXT. DICKIE'S TERRACE. LATE DAY. Marge and Ripley and Dickie watch from the terrace as bel them an AMBULANCE takes away the body. It seems as if the whole town looks on - fiancee, parents, brothers, sisters police, priest, etc. As the corpse is loaded into the veh A BRIEF SCUFFLE occurs between Silvana's fiancee and her brother. They are pulled apart. Then the ambulance pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the fight about? That's her fiancГ€, isn't it?  Are they blaming him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! Why are you asking me? (agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can it take an hour to find an ambulance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she was already dead, darling, wasn't she, so I suppose -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why people say this country's civilised. It isn't. It's fucking primitive. And with that HE KICKS OUT VIOLENTLY AT A CHAIR SUPPORTIN THE RECORDPLAYER. Records, machine, chair go flying acros the terrace. Dickie storms inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go and see what's the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go. INT. DICKIE'S HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON. Later, Dickie is slumped in an armchair at the open windo overlooking the slipway. He's playing sax. A forlorn, kee phrase from YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT LOVE IS. Ripley appears, begins tidying the mess in the living room.  He picks up empty bottles, an abandoned bikini top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why you're upset. (Dickie continues playing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know about Silvana, Dickie. About you and Silvana. Dickie stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about us? He now has an armful of dishes and glasses and bottles. DICKIE (cont'd) (losing his temper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to clean up! Really! Ripley disappears into the kitchen. DICKIE (cont'd) (as Ripley returns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was pregnant. Did you know that? Do you know what that means in a place like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm prepared to take the blame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been so good to me. You're the brother I never had. I'm the brother you never had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came to me for help, she needed money, and I didn't help her. I didn't help her. Now she's dead and it's my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to say anything - to Marge, or anybody, the police - It's a secret between us and I'll keep it. And he disappears again, leaving Dickie to resume the sax somehow in thrall to Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Tom, I think the time has come to discontinue your expense checks... EXT. AMERICAN EXPRESS, NAPLES. DAY. Ripley and Dickie are walking out of the American Express Office, Dickie pushing the rest of his money into his cas Ripley - despondent - reading aloud extracts from a lette from Herbert Greenleaf -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The thousand dollars, of course, was only due in the event that you succeeded in bringing Dickie home. Naturally, I hope the trip has afforded you some pleasure despite the failure of its main objective you need no longer consider yourself obligated to us in any way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't blame him.  You could hardly expect this to go on forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might write again. Now that we're brothers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, how can I, in all decency? We've had a good run, haven't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (increasingly miserable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Venice? Can we stick to that plan at least?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Tom. You can't stay on here without money.  It's time we all moved on.  Besides I'm sick of Mongi. Especially now with everything - I really want to move to the North. I need to check out San Remo next week, find somewhere new to keep the boat. But it would be great, though, if you came with me.  Our last trip before you leave. There's a jazz festival - we could say goodbye in style.  What do you think? A last trip? INT. TRAIN TO SAN REMO. AFTERNOON. Dickie and Ripley travel up to San Remo. They sit next to each other. Dickie's asleep. Ripley lays his head on Dick shoulder, but as he does that, the ticket inspector annou the San Remo stop, taps on the window and Dickie stirs. T Ripley plays his familiar game of studying his face in th reflection of the train window, so that he can move his h and see his reflection, then back and see Dickie's.  Dick suddenly catches him staring. Ripley looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do that thing - with your neck? On trains you always do that thing, it's so spooky. EXT. HOTEL TERRACE RESTAURANT, SAN REMO. NIGHT. Dickie and Ripley walk through the terrace of an hotel wh lips out towards the sea. There's a restaurant and palms a JAZZ QUINTET playing, American. Very cool. They pass th band. Dickie's captivated as they head for their table. T pass some girls at a table. Dickie smiles greedily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is more like it. Didn't I tell you San Remo was crazy! They're shown to a good table. Dickie watches the band wh their glasses are filled with champagne. Ripley looks hap He's got Dickie all to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Mongibello and the happiest days of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Mongi.  You're cheerful tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm suddenly quite happy to be going back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got plans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley's plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esatto. I'm always planning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I know you at Princeton, Tom? I didn't, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you asking all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason. Because you're leaving, I guess. I don't think you were there, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it as a compliment. You've got such great taste, I don't know. Most of the thugs at Princeton had tasted everything and had no taste. Used to say, the cream of America: rich and thick. Freddie's the perfect example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll take it as a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it! I had a bet with Marge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even like jazz - or was that something for my benefit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conceding, without guile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotten to like it. I've gotten to like everything about the way you live. It's one big love affair. If you knew my life back home in New York... Dickie's distracted by the drummer who's playing an extro solo, doesn't hear the confession of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of giving up the sax, what do you think about drums?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So cool. He mimes a high-hat and snare. Ripley can't quite credit - it's superficiality. EXT. MID OCEAN. DAY. The bay of San Remo. DICKIE and RIPLEY have hired a motor boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I found my place in Mongi. Took a boat out round the bay.  The first place I liked, I got it. The motor boat is ploughing the waves. Dickie exhilarated the speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie, slow down, come on! Ripley grips the oar, his knuckles white. Dickie cuts the motor, and the boat slows to a crawl, miles from the shor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ecstatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it here! Gonna live here! Dickie takes off his jacket, then drums against the edge the boat, developing a rhythm with his lighter and finger already on the way to becoming Buddy Rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you my plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I might come back. In the New Year. Under my own steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly tight)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  To Italy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Let's say, for argument's sake, you were here - perhaps we could split the rent on a house - I'll get a job - or, better still, I could get a place in Rome and when we're there we could be there and if we're here we could be here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - you see, particularly with the Marge problem, you can just blame me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge and I are getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday you're ogling girls on the terrace, today you're getting married. It's absurd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Marge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love me and you're not marrying me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, I don't love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it's not a threat, I've explained all of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm actually a little relieved you're going, to be honest. I think we've seen enough of each other for a while. Ripley stares at him, his eyes suddenly reptilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be a leech - you know this - and it's boring. You can be quite boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (volcanic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funny thing - I'm not pretending to be somebody else and you are. I'm absolutely honest with you. I've told you my feelings. But you, first of all I know there's something - that evening when we played chess, for instance, it was obvious -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure - I know, that's too dangerous for you, fair enough, hey! we're brothers, fine, then you do this sordid thing with Marge, fucking her on the boat while we all have to listen, which was excruciating, frankly, plus you follow your cock around like a - and now you're getting married! I'm bewildered, forgive me...you're lying to Marge then getting married to her, you're knocking up Silvana, you've got to play sax, you've got to play drums, which is it, Dickie, what do you really play? Dickie, furious, gets up, and lurches towards Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attacking him, administering tiny slaps as punctuation to his tirade)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you - some imposter, some third class mooch - who are you to tell me anything? Actually, I really really really don't want to be on this boat with you, I can't move without you moving, which is exactly how it feels and it gives me the creeps. (he goes to rev up the engine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't move without - "Dickie, Dickie, Dickie" - like a little girl.  You give me the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Just shut up! Just shut up! The boat slows as Dickie releases the tiller.  Dickie loo up at Ripley wearily and slides onto his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake. Ripley, shocked at himself, goes to Dickie, rocking the b catches him up, then is horrified to see Dickie's face, apparently unmarked, SUDDENLY SPLIT OPEN, a line of blood then a peeling like a fruit bursting. Ripley's appalled. terrible roar issues from Dickie as he launches himself a Ripley. DICKIE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you! Ripley finds himself pushing him away, picking up the oar kicking off Dickie's hand around his ankle. The boat is rocking and swerving crazily as Dickie falls against the tiller. Ripley almost loses his balance. His glasses come off. They struggle, locked together in a life or death wrestle to get control of the oar. Dickie's blinded by hi own blood, loses his grip. Ripley, terrified, hits Dickie again and again, the oar l a carpet-beater banging down flat, blood on the blade, bl on Ripley, until he's on his knees, heaving for breath, letting his arm drop, then realizing, disgusted, that he' let it rest in a pool of blood. He starts to sob, sprawls there, sobbing, next to Dickie, horrified by what he's do Nobody's in sight.  The boat rocks, gently, the sun spark indifferently on the waves.  Ripley lies by Dickie in the bottom of the boat, in the embrace he's always wanted. The pretty blue-and-white boat rocks peacefully.  The sea calms. EXT. A COVE NEAR SAN REMO. AFTERNOON. A deserted cove, several miles along the coast. Ripley clambers onto a rock over the shore.  He's watching the b slowly sinking. Shuddering from the exertion, the cold, h finds Dickie's jacket, puts it on and watches as the boat disappears under the surface. EXT. SAN REMO. DUSK. Ripley walks back towards the hotel, still wearing Dickie jacket, cold and wet, his bag over his shoulder. INT. HOTEL LOBBY. EARLY EVENING. Ripley approaches the front desk.  He's shivering.  He's wearing his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have my key, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the key rack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course - But you must be very cold? Signor Greenleaf?  Yes? -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mind racing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's - I'm... EXT. ROAD BETWEEN NAPLES AND MONGIBELLO. DAY. Ripley sits on the bus as it rumbles towards Mongi. He stares out of the window, full of what he's done. No idea what to do. EXT. MONGIBELLO, FISHERMAN'S WHARF. DAY. The BUS comes into town. Ripley gets out, looks calm, ver together. INT. DICKIE'S LIVING ROOM, MONGIBELLO. DAY. Ripley walks into the living room, slowly approaches Dickie's saxophone which is on its stand on the table. H can't get close to it, it evokes Dickie too much. INT. DICKIE'S LIVING ROOM. DAY. Ripley has Dickie's Hermes Baby typewriter on the desk an busy writing letters. He has finished a letter to the Greenleafs, now he's at the end of one to Marge. We can r part of it - C/O American Express, Rome 9 November 195 Marge, this is a difficult letter for me to write... produces the Shakespeare and Signature page and COPIES DICKIE'S SIGNATURE at the end of the letter. EXT. MARGE'S GARDEN, MONGIBELLO. DAY. Ripley stands at the entrance to Marge's garden where she working at her book on the outside table, surrounded by references and notes, held down by bricks. He looks at he until she looks at him. She's startled, gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Marge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, you startled me!  You're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? Sorry. Is your book going well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes - I'm on a good streak, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just looking at you - (looking at her tenderly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - so quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's planning on staying in Rome for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha. Did he say why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't understand Dickie, Marge, so your guess is as good as mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, one day I'm invited skiing, the next day I'm not, one day we're all one family, the next day he wants to be alone. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what he said - he wanted to be alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was thinking of you, Marge - he asked me to deliver this. He hands her a package. She pulls at it, it's perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. he knows I love this, although why it couldn't have waited...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Errand number one - deliver Marge's perfume. Errand number two, pack some clothes and his precious saxophone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's he staying for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search me. I guess we're abandoned. EXT. MONGIBELLO, BEACH. EARLY MORNING. Marge is walking along the beach and out onto the jetty, forlorn, a bleached figure on this winter morning. INT. OFF FROM DICKIE'S LIVING ROOM. MORNING. As Ripley walks down the stairs, Marge is at the icebox i the living room. She's fixing herself a drink, has the ic open for ice. She's ashen, and might have been weeping, w back into the kitchen area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a letter from Dickie in with my perfume. You realize it's more than a few days? He's thinking of moving to Rome. She bangs out the ice onto the counter, cubes falling everywhere. Ripley drops to the floor and starts to clear them up.  She's got the letter, shows it to Ripley. He pu fresh ice into her glass. MARGE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, the night before he left, we talked about moving, together, going North - and I suppose I put some pressure on him, about getting married, I just might have scared him off. There's a side to him, when our heads are on the pillow, I know no-one else sees it, which is really tender. (unravelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should come with you to Rome and just confront him. Ripley lights a cigarette.  Marge loses confidence. MARGE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hates being confronted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're right. INT. ALBERGO GOLDONI, ROME. DAY. RIPLEY'S BATTERED CASES are carried into the tiny lobby o this small hotel. He exchanges his passport at the desk f his room key, then makes his way, carrying his own luggag the metal cage elevator. THIS SCENE INTERCUTS WITH: INT. HOTEL GRAND. DAY. DICKIE'S ARRAY OF LEATHER LUGGAGE is pulled along on a  baggage trolley by a liveried PORTER. Dickie's passport slides across the marble desk. A key co back, collected by a hand sporting Dickie's two distincti rings.  As ALDO, the Front Desk Manager, inspects the passport, he looks at the owner.  Ripley wears a terrific suit, his hair parted in the Greenleaf style, no glasses. voice, when he speaks, has the same, lazy, confident draw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back, Signor Greenleaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. RIPLEY'S SUITE, GRAND. DAY. The PORTER takes the cases and opens them as Ripley walks around the suite. It's large and splendid. Ripley breathe its opulence.  He immediately picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'd like you to telephone the Hotel Goldoni. Yes. I want to speak to Signor Thomas Ripley - No Ripley, R, yes. Grazie. He produces Dickie's pen and signs the blotter quickly - Greenleaf. Then he pulls out a postcard from the wri case to reveal Dickie's Stars, hide your fires han specimen. He compares the two signatures, is pleased. The telephone rings. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pronto? Signor Ripley is not there? I'd like to leave a message. Yes. Please call Dickie - Dickie Greenleaf - at the Grand. INT. RIPLEY'S HOTEL ROOM, GOLDONI. DAY. A tiny, cell of a room, single bed. Ripley on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not there? Very well. I'll leave a message - Got your call. Dinner tonight sounds fine. Ripley. (listens as it's read back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner tonight, yes, is okay. Yes, thank you. INT. GUCCI STORE, ROME. DAY. Ripley has bought some more LEATHER GOODS - a briefcase a overnight bag. He is at the counter, signing checks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like these to have my initials - embossed, I don't know the word in Italian ...embossed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embossed, of course, Signor Greenleaf. There's an excited rap on the window and a shout of DICKI Shocked, Ripley looks over to find MEREDITH LOGUE outside alone and delighted to see him.  He grins and mouths hell

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering the shop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie! Oh my God!  Ciao. EXT. ACROSS PIAZZA NAVONA TO ARCARI'S CAFE. DAY. Ripley and Meredith walk across the Piazza towards the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're going skiing with us Yankees, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Christmas. To Cortina with Freddie Miles and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, astonished)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody knows Freddie Miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsettled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Freddie in Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? I don't think so. But I've met him, of course, and we've chatted and I know about you and Marge and Mongi and what an unreliable rat you are. Freddie said you were a rat and I thought to myself now I know why he travels under R.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've left Marge, Meredith. And Mongi. So the rat's here now, in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I wouldn't have made a joke if -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry. I've never been happier. I feel like I've been handed a new life. EXT. AMERICAN EXPRESS OFFICE, ROME. DAY. Meredith and Ripley walk down the Spanish Steps and head inside the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is if you've had money your entire life, even if you despise it, which we do - agreed? - you're only truly comfortable around other people who have it and despise it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never admitted that to anyone. INT. AMERICAN EXPRESS OFFICE, ROME. DAY. Ripley's signing Dickie's allowance receipt. Meredith is him, signing her own counterfoil.
