He is, of course, endor by her presence.  She goes to the window ahead of him. She takes her money, turns to him. He hands over his documents. The Clerk compares Ripley's signature with the one on the passport and then looks up him. Ripley is cool as a cucumber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want too many large bills. Nobody will change them. INT. RIPLEY'S SUITE, GRAND. ANOTHER DAY. Where A TAILOR is finishing the fitting of a cashmere jac for Ripley. Bolts of cloth everywhere as Meredith adjudic the possible materials, which the tailor holds up against Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me the other one again. (the Tailor obliges)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take them both. Ripley goes inside the bedroom to change. While he's insi Meredith shows the Tailor out.  As she returns she notice the open sax case, peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're a jazz fiend but do you absolutely hate the Opera?  I've been trying to give my tickets away, it's tomorrow, but if you were prepared to be dragged... She looks up to catch him bare-chested. She's intoxicated him, the romance she feels to be in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emerging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could drag me. INT. THE OPERA HOUSE, ROME. On stage is Act Two of Eugene Onegin.  Lensky sings his a before the duel with Onegin. Ripley's in a tuxedo, in a box which includes a glamorous Meredith and her AUNT AND UNCLE.  He knows what comes nex Lensky is shot by Onegin. Blood pours from his neck into snow.  Onegin, horrified at the death of his friend, goes over, wraps Lensky in his cloak, the silk lining flashing kneels holding him... Ripley can barely hide his emotion. Meredith watches her sensitive friend, entranced. INT. OUTSIDE THE BOXES, OPERA HOUSE, ROME. The Interval.  Ripley and Meredith exit their box with Meredith's Aunt and Uncle (who heads for the interval drinks).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks so much for inviting me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you bear it? We hear you're a friend of Freddie's - he has I hate Opera tattooed on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's room for a whole libretto on Freddie's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we've met. They reach the console where Uncle Ted has their drinks. JOAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sure we'd met, weren't you, Ted? This is Herbert Greenleaf's boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, yes, I think we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute you people are children and the next you're getting tattooed. INT. OPERA HOUSE, FOYER. NIGHT. Ripley heads past the Beautiful People on his hunt for th Men's Room, and walks straight into a young and cultured Englishman.  They greet each other and suddenly MARGE is beside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if she's seen a ghost)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, how are you? What are you doing in Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he here? Are you with Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (to Smith-Kingsley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Tom Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Smith-Kingsley. I've heard about you, of course - from Marge, and Dickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (works out what's strange)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No glasses. He fishes out the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ditto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you hiding him? He's impossible, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he really not here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, you know Dickie has I hate Opera tattooed on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were going to Venice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what happened? I heard you were desperate to come. I was looking forward to rowing you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  I really am. And I've been travelling. I just can't seem to get that far north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hurry, before we sink. (reaches into his jacket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I give you my telephone number in Venice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. The INTERVAL BELL'S ringing. Peter hands over his card to Ripley, sees Meredith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look there's Meredith thingy - who's that, Marge? - they're in textiles... Meredith - (embarrassed at not remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, how awful, I've spent Christmas in her house...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know her. (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't called, he's hardly written, just these cryptic notes. You don't just dump people. The last INTERVAL BELL. There's a mini-stampede to return

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will we see you later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow's possible. Do you know Dinelli's? Piazza di Spagna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the Piazza di Spagna. What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten thirty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Marge, see you tomorrow. (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really good to meet you. INT. BOX, OPERA HOUSE. NIGHT. Ripley goes straight to Meredith and grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were enjoying yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a Carozza and look at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy! It's freezing out there. He's looking past her, where a mirror reflects Marge wadi through the audience, Peter's elegant head getting dangerously near as they approach their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I need to talk to you. Just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite taken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then, you're crazy. EXT. CAROZZA, ROME. NIGHT. Meredith shivers in the raw night as they cross the Tiber Ripley as Dickie is confessing his heart belongs to Marge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Really. Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a pal to understand. It's as if Marge is here now - I look at you and I see her face - and I can't, whatever I'm feeling towards you - I just can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I absolutely understand. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise you'd be fighting me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beating you away. EXT. MEREDITH'S APARTMENT, ROME. They arrive at the courtyard outside Meredith's Apartment Building. Ripley jumps down, collects her. She makes to g inside, then looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you meet me tomorrow?  Just to say goodbye in the daylight, properly? So it's not just this, it's too...you should always save pain for daylight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Meredith, I'm sorry. Of course I'll meet you. Let's have coffee in the morning at Dinelli's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fluttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't - is that by the Spanish Steps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. 10.30 - (instantly correcting himself)

He gets back into the carozza. It moves off. EXT. DINELLI'S CAFE, PIAZZA DI SPAGNA. MORNING. Meredith sits waiting in a cafe at the bottom of the Span Steps. Ripley, dressed as Ripley, is at the top of the st among early tourists, watching as she drinks her coffee a outside table. Then Marge and Peter appear walking up the Condotti, head for another table, don't see Meredith.  Sh acknowledges Peter who hasn't noticed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter? Hello, it's Meredith Logue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is, Meredith, hello, I'm sorry, half-asleep, how are you? This is Marge Sherwood. Meredith Logue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Hearing Marge's name Meredith reacts, freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join us, won't you? We're just waiting for a friend. Do you know, I wonder did we see you at the Opera last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't actually, although I think this might - are you waiting for Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well no, as it happens, although...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned at the mention of his name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie? Do you know Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were at the Opera? Well, that explains - yes I was there. I was there with Dickie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you! I knew it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving over to them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, I don't know you, so I have no right, but Dickie loves you.  He's - I think you'll find he's coming home to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proprietorial)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me everything. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I...I'm going to go now, I think. Unless he meant us to meet - which would be a little cruel, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're meeting another friend. Tom Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley? No. I heard about him, of course, but no, I didn't meet him. The WAITER has arrived to take orders. Meredith indicates she's leaving. MEREDITH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me. No, grazie. Marge is on the edge. Peter lays a hand to comfort her. MEREDITH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I didn't complicate matters, but nothing, nothing untoward happened, nothing to prevent you from welcoming him back, from marrying him...Goodbye. Goodbye Peter, please don't get up. Peter gets up. Ripley, from his vantage point at the top the steps, watches Meredith leave and walk off into the crowd. He begins the slow walk down towards the square. A becomes visible to the cafe, he starts to hurry. He's apologising to Marge and Peter as they see him, in his element, lying and believing in his lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry. Had to renew my papers. Italian bureaucracy - never one stamp when they can make you line up for three. Have you been waiting long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Morning Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (to Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. You okay? You look as if you've seen a ghost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie was at the Opera last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. Wild horses wouldn't drag Dickie to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was there with someone. So I suppose she must have dragged him - that's not fair.  I'm going back to Mongi. I think Dickie's coming home. (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? That's swell. No, I was just - you're way ahead of me! Great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think he's had a change of heart. (to Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we should be celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was moving, wasn't it? When Meredith said - (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith's the American girl I saw last night, I know her, at the Opera, she's been seeing something of Dickie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the point is Dickie - well we know this - Dickie loves Marge and he misses her and apparently he's come to his senses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fantastic. (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel guilty. Marge doesn't understand this, but anytime Dickie does something I feel guilty. INT. APARTMENT, PALAZZA GIOIA. DAY. Ripley is being shown an APARTMENT FOR RENT in the Palazz Gioia by a dry-witted older woman, SIGNORA BUFFI. Ripley explores, relishing the decor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accendo il riscaldamento. (I'll turn the heating on.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimes playing sax)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mi piace suonare. (I like to play music.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Io sono sorda. Quelli di sotto, una coppia, sono sordi. Allora, ti piace? (I'm deaf. The couple below are deaf. So, do you like it?) INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. AFTERNOON. Ripley is in the apartment, fire burning, wearing pyjamas There's a small Christmas tree. He kneels on the floor wi some festive, gift-wrapped packages. He opens a package. a marble head of Hadrian. A gasp from Ripley. He picks up glass, pours himself a drink. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. LATE AFTERNOON. Ripley plunges into Bach's Italian Concerto on his new an precious toy, a STEINWAY GRAND. His doorbell rings. He st playing. He doesn't get visitors. He rises, a little nerv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Freddie. Let me in. RIPLEY ALMOST COLLAPSES. He's faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie, come on, it's me. Ripley can't think what to hide, where to hide. He opens door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Freddie, it's Tom, Tom Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused, not pleasantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hello, where's Dickie? How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm good, thank you. Dickies at dinner. He's at Otello's. Do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he's at dinner at 6.30pm. If you said he was still at lunch I'd believe you. Incredible. The guy has disappeared off the face of the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landlady - as far as I could tell, the landlady said he was here right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone to dinner! Search the place. I can't think why you would imagine Dickie would hide from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's been hiding from me - what happened at Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was supposed to come skiing. I didn't get a cable or a call or a note or, frankly, a fart. Ripley has his hands behind his back. HE'S TUGGING FRANTICALLY AT DICKIE'S RINGS. Ripley wanders into the kitchen, turns on the tap to sluice his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, he's been very involved in his music, hasn't he? I think his theory is, you know, you have to go into a cocoon before you can become a butterfly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is horseshit.  Have you heard him play that thing? (gesturing at the sax on its stand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find him? It's such an out of the way apartment. Can I fix you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. (explaining his detective work)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kid at the American Express Office. (he starts to explore)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you living here? Now he starts to hammer a nasty boogie-woogie on the pian

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning, flinching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I'm staying here for a few days, in Rome.  That's a new piano, so you prob -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did this place come furnished? It doesn't look like Dickie. Horrible isn't it? - so bourgeois. Now he's poking at the Hadrian bust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should watch that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact the only thing which looks like Dickie is you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you done something to your hair? Ripley starts to smile, his eyes darting around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie, do you have something to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I think I'm saying it. Something's going on. He's either converted to Christianity - or to something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suggest you ask Dickie that yourself. Otello's is on delle Croce, just off the Corso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it on "delle Croce, just off the Corso"? You're a quick study, aren't you? Last time you didn't know your ass from your elbow, now you're giving me directions. That's not fair, you probably do know your ass from your elbow. I'll see you. AND HE'S GONE. Ripley shuts the door, smooths the silk ru on the table where Freddie's hand had rucked it. He goes to the door, opens it and looks over the rail. INT. LANDING AND STAIRS, RIPLEY'S BUILDING. LATE DAY. FREDDIE IS BACK IN CONVERSATION WITH SIGNORA BUFFI. Riple can't make out the text but there's some discussion about Signor Greenleaf and Signor Ripley. Ripley Freddie's heavy shoes start to clump up the stairs again. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT, ROME. LATE DAY. Freddie knocks on the door which pushes open. As he march in, he launches into his interrogation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripley? There's someth -

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY MARBLE SCULPTURE.
dialogues.text: Freddie falls like an ox, first to his knees, groaning, t to the floor as Ripley brings the head down again, beatin him downwards. As Freddie slumps away, Ripley loses his balance and the head sends Freddie a glancing blow before slipping from Ripley's grasp and smashing on to the floor THE NOSE IS CHIPPED OFF. EXT. PALAZZO GIOIA. NIGHT. It's deserted. Ripley hauls Freddie out of the shadows towards the car. A couple walk across the square. Ripley talks to Freddie, berating him for his drunken stupor. He pushes him over the door and into the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Freddie's voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if I'm drunk, think what her husband's saying. EXT. VIA APPIA ANTICA. NIGHT. The Fiat noses along THE APPIAN WAY. Black fragments of t punctuate either side of the poorly lit road. Inside the Ripley looks to left and right for a place to dump the bo He slows near a clump of trees. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT, ROME. EVENING. Someone is KNOCKING urgently at the door. Ripley opens it finds himself face to face with Signora Buffi and TWO POLICEMEN. One of them offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie Greenleaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Roverini. Can we come in? INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. EVENING. Ripley sits with his head in his hands at the table. Rove and his sergeant, BAGGIO, watch patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a terrible shock, eh? What time did Signor Miles leave yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be absolutely sure - 8? 9? We'd both taken on far too many drinks - but it was dark, it was certainly dark when I walked him down to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Signor Miles drove away and you did what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to bed. Freddie's a big man, but I'm in trouble after a couple of drinks. I've suffered all day. Who found him? Roverini has walked over to the bust of Hadrian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senta.  We have to ask you to stay in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, if it's going to help, certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the Doctor, he has to make the - (looks at Baggio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - come se dice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postmortem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, exactly, but his first, his first conclusion was that Signor Miles was killed not later than seven o'clock yesterday evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he certainly wasn't dead when he drove off in his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. EXT. NARROW STREET, THE GHETTO, ROME. MORNING. Ripley comes through a dark tunnel in the Ghetto on his scooter. He drives past a furniture store, DRESSING TABLE AND MIRRORS spilling out onto the street. He glances sideways, sees his reflection fractured into several imag and, for an instant, it seems AS IF DICKIE'S THERE WATCHING HIM. Ripley screams and swerves, crashing into t pavement, the scooter falling onto him and pulling him al the cobbled passage. The man he thought to be Dickie, an Italian, runs up concerned. EXT. AMERICAN EXPRESS, PIAZZA DI SPAGNA. DAY. Ripley emerges from the American Express Office. Across t street at the cafe, as once before, sits Marge. Ripley sl Dickie's bag into his knapsack as he approaches his scoot Marge spots him and strides across the piazza. She is in mood for pleasantries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he kill Freddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, when did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me the truth. Did he kill Freddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd swear he didn't. Of course he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried again, waiting here, watching for him. Instead it's you. Whenever I look for Dickie I find you. (focusing on Ripley's cuts and bruises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly tense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My face! There was an argument. I said some things I shouldn't have.  About you. About the appalling way he's treating you, all of us.  And the next thing I know he's launched himself at me. (he pulls the scooter off the stand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you getting on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on. I'll take you to him. EXT. SQUARE OF THE PALAZZO GIOIA. DAY. Ripley and Marge come round the corner on the scooter. Th entrance to the Palazzo is blocked by a couple of police Inspector Roverini emerges from one of them. Ripley, startled, drives straight past the entrance. EXT. ROME STREET, BY THE RIVER. DAY. Ripley pulls up several hundred yards later, in a differe piazza full of book stalls.  Marge is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does Dickie live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We passed it a few blocks back, where the police were. The Palazzo Gioia. They don't even know I'm in Rome and I'm not going to incriminate Dickie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I shouldn't go either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking hard, distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, well go if you want to, but don't talk to the Police about my face - they find out he hit me - he's got a temper - he could've hit Freddie. (sincerely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Marge. I'll catch up with you later. And he drives off. At the first opportunity HE DOUBLES BA and roars towards the Palazzo. EXT. SQUARE OF THE PALAZZO GIOIA. AFTERNOON. Ripley drives towards the entrance.  As Ripley gets off a pushes his scooter through the doorway SOME JOURNALISTS, LOITERING INSIDE A BARBER'S SHOP come running out and swa around him with questions about Freddie. One of them gets a photograph.  It's chaos, a Police Officer shouts him aw as Ripley puts up a protective hand and runs inside. INT. ENTRANCE AND STAIRS, PALAZZO GIOIA. CONTINUOUS. As Ripley hurries inside he encounters officers conductin more thorough forensic investigations in the stairwell. O landing is Roverini. Ripley hurries towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go up? Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My scooter. I fell off. Getting chased by photographers. He hurries up the stairs, Roverini in tow. RIPLEY (cont'd) (agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone, the press, I've been, I'm feeling hounded - do you think you could not give out my address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. We've had many requests and, of course, we say no - even to your fiancГ€e.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't want to see anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even your fiancГ€e...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Thomas Ripley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Ripley? Ripley's way ahead and has reached the door of his apartm He waits nervously for Roverini. He unlocks the door and barely wait for Roverini to catch up. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT. AFTERNOON. Roverini follows Ripley inside, Baggio hurries in behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Signor Ripley went to San Remo, is that right? Ripley is appalled. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, we did go to San Remo. That was months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November, I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it? Did you speak to Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November 7th is my information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember the exact date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when did you last see Signor Ripley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he stay with you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Here is a pattern. Two days ago Freddie Miles is dead - he leaves your apartment and is murdered. Yesterday a little boat is found in San Remo full of rocks, and the owner tells the Police it was stolen on November 7th. We look at hotel records and we see oh! Dickie Greenleaf is staying in San Remo and then our boatman remembers two Americans taking a boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a pattern, it's a coincidence. There must be fifty hotels in San Remo, there must have been a hundred people renting a boat on that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 people. Baggio appears. Speaks to Roverini. Ripley is getting cra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is Miss Sherwood now. Marge Sherwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled, defeated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her in, what's the difference?  Let her in. (Baggio is on his way to the door.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually, no, I'd like it very much if you would ask her to come back later. Roverini nods, mutters to Baggio, who heads out. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask...why would you speak to your friend and not your fiancГ€e?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I just said. Ripley was handling some business for me, nor does Mr Ripley want to marry me.  Nor did he ask me every day if I would marry him. And when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a photograph of Signor Ripley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in the habit of carrying around photographs of my male friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I think I have upset you. My English perhaps is coarse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a little coarse, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  No-one has seen Signor Ripley since San -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have and so has Miss Sherwood, ask her! and if I could remember which hotel he was staying at - the Goldoni! - Tom was staying at the Goldoni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. The Goldoni. Yes - you're right. A coincidence. (he gets up to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look forward to our next meeting when I will be more careful with my English and persuade you to play me your saxophone. Alto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a witness who thinks they saw two men getting into Mr Miles' car. She wants to identify you in a - confronto - line-up. (ominously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown, scrabbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Ripley lets them out, heaves a heavy sigh, then peeps thr the door, looks down to see Roverini speaking to Marge on stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buongiorno, Miss Sherwood. He's in but I really don't think he wants to see anyone. Ripley leans against the door, the noose tightening, then suddenly a voice shocks him upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick? Dickie? I know you can hear me. What am I doing, chasing you around...? I was going to say I would count to three and if you didn't open the door, but I won't count any more. On you. I won't count on you any more. Whatever it is, whatever you've done or haven't done, you've broken my heart. That's one thing I know you're guilty of, and I don't know why, I don't know why, I just don't know why... Ripley listens, there's a silence, then Marge's footsteps they ring out on the stone stairs. The tapping sound reso into the tap-tap of a manual typewriter. INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT, PALAZZO GIOIA. NIGHT. Ripley's at the typewriter, he begins to type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Tom, I'm getting out of this. Freddie's death, Silvana. I've thought about going to the police, but I can't do it, I can't face it. I can't face anything anymore... INT. RIPLEY'S APARTMENT, PALAZZO GIOIA. NIGHT. CHAOS. Ripley is working quickly, selecting clothes, dividing them into TWO PILES - one for Dickie's trunk, on for his own battered suitcase. He puts the license plates from Freddie's car in Dickie's luggage. He has placed one shirt on the Ripley pile then checks again, and - on seei Dickie's initials, places it with the bigger pile, then p it up again and holds it briefly against his cheek. He takes Dickie's rings, opens up a LITTLE BOX of buttons needles and cufflinks and sadly tosses them in. Dickie's leather writing case goes on the big pile, too, as do cuf links, ties, the Mont Blanc, Dickie's passport, which he opens to scratch at the photograph, obliterating the face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I wish I could give you the life I took for granted. You've always understood what's at the heart of me, Tom. Marge never could. I suppose that's why I'm writing this to you, the brother I never had. The only true friend I ever had. In all kinds of ways you're much more like the son my father always wanted. I realise you can change the people, change the scenery, but you can't change your own rotten self. Now I can't think what to do, or where to go. I'm haunted by everything I've done, and can't undo. I'm sorry, I can't go on. I've made a mess of being Dickie Greenleaf haven't I? He's finished the letter, signs it, puts it in an envelop marked Tom Ripley and places the letter on top of the pia next to Dickie's passport. His head is reflected in the distorting curve of the lid. As he puts on his glasses there's a moment when there are two heads slowly separati as Ripley leaves behind his brief life as Dickie Greenlea INT. BASEMENT, PALAZZO GIOIA. NIGHT. Ripley carries Dickie's luggage down into THE COMMUNAL BASEMENT of the Gioia, a wretched place full of shadows a gloom and the overflow from thirty apartments. A red plus couch sits on top of a mound of furniture. He finds some dustsheets and shoves the cases under them. Then Dickie's saxophone. Outside the small window, Ripley sees uniformed feet and revolving blue light of a Police Car. He shrinks back, tu off the light and disappears into the dark, illuminated fitfully by the strobe of cold blue. EXT. BY THE PALAZZO GIOIA, ROME. NIGHT. Ripley, familiar battered luggage in tow, appears at the entrance of the building next to his own, glances at the police car parked opposite the big doors, then hurries of into the darkness. EXT. BY THE PALAZZO GIOIA. NIGHT. Ripley's briefly silhouetted as he scuttles down an alley hurrying towards a gate, and disappears behind it. EXT. PIAZZALE ROMA, VENICE. DAWN. Ripley sits next to his battered luggage at the prow of a MOTOR TAXI as it surges towards Venice at dawn. Peter Smi Kingsley waits on the quay. Ripley waves. Peter waves bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the taxi stop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you over there! EXT. PIAZZA SAN MARCO, VENICE. EARLY MORNING. Ripley and Peter walk through the square, the pigeons scattering. Ripley breathes in the atmosphere, the beauti grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I'm really sorry to put you through this. I just couldn't face going to the police by myself when my Italian's so rotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be daft. It's fine. I'm delighted you finally made it to Venice. I'm delighted, contrary to rumour, you're still in one piece?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What rumour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Dickie murdered you and is travelling under your passport. I know, ridiculous. INT. POLICE STATION, VENICE. LATE DAY. Later.  Ripley sits in the middle of a bustling Police St where thefts, tourists, thieves and complaints are being processed.  The Station is in an old brewery or armory. I horrible, monochrome, oppressive place. Peter is in conversation at a desk, turns and walks over to where Rip waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Venice.  This place reeks, doesn't it? Can you smell it?  Ugh. Sorry. Not the best way to spend your first day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway I've got to the bottom of the delay. Finally.  We're waiting for someone from Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely thrown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  They're sending someone from Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if suffocating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I thought that didn't happen in Italy, that each region was completely separate! I was sure that was the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen the papers, you know what a big deal it's been here. American tourist murdered -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous but now you've mentioned the stench I can hardly breathe. A door opens. COLONEL VERRECCHIA, fresh from Rome, and a sullen wedge of a man, comes in, scowling at the couple. Ripley dare not look up in case it's Roverini.  A POLICEM introduces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonelo Verrecchia della Polizia di Roma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter, in Italian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qui e Ripley? Who is Ripley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lui. Him. Verrecchia strides past them and into a smaller, intervie room at the back of the station. His manner is ominous. INT. POLICE STATION, INTERVIEW ROOM, VENICE. LATE DAY. This room is not at all friendly. There is evidence of a locked area for cells at one wall. A small, sour window gives onto a canal. The main station is glimpsed through some internal windows. Peter and Ripley come through. Verrecchia sits down. Verrecchia talks in staccato Itali during which Peter translates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho assunto io la guida delle indagini in seguito alla negativa valutazione delle disdicevoli circostanze verificatesi con il mio predecessore Roverini che come e noto non e riuscito a impedire il verificarsi della scomparsa del signor Greenleaf, il quale era l'unica persona al momento passibile di incriminazione del reato di omicidio del signor Miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's taken over the case because... they're annoyed the previous chap let Dickie...disappear when he was the only, he was the only suspect in Freddie's murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quando e stata l'ultima volta che il signor Ripley ha visto il signor Greenleaf? (When was the last time Ripley saw Greenleaf?) Ripley forgets he's not supposed to have much Italian and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Rome, about three weeks ago. (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving Ripley a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Roma, circa tre settimane fa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dove e stato il signor Ripley da allora?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been since then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been backpacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to translate that. (he tries)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E difficile....il signor Ripley ....dormiva all'aperto, con un...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All'aperto? Col freddo che ha fatto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks it's very cold to be sleeping outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il signor Ripley ha sviluppate tendenze omosessuali?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a homosexual? (then as himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting non-sequitur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translates for him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (as Peter, drily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, officially there are no Italian homosexuals. Makes Leonardo, Michelangelo very inconvenient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I have a fiancГ€e, Dickie has a fiancГ€e and Freddie Miles probably had a string of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il signor Ripley ha una fidanzata, il signor Dickie ha una fidanzata e probabilmente il signor Freddie Miles ha molte fidanzate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma mia, quante fidanzate! They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says so many fiancГ€es.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly very tough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lei ha ucciso prima Freddie Miles e dopo Dickie Greenleaf! Vero? As Peter translates Verrecchia watches intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to know if you killed Freddie Miles and then killed Dickie Greenleaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I did not. I did not kill Freddie Miles and then kill Dickie Greenleaf.  Is he accusing me? (Peter clearly doesn't ask)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him if he's accusing me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's already angry, I don't think -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, heated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because he doesn't like Americans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non e questo il luogo per le vostre conversazioni private! (This is not the place for your private conversations)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appeasing him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ragione. A ragione. (You're right. You're right.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. C'e questa... (There's this...) Verrecchia hands over a letter. It's opened. Ripley's nam the outside. Ripley stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Questa lettera e stata trovata nell'abitazione del signor Richard Greenleaf a Roma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found this in Dickie's place in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You opened this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! He stands and takes the letter out.  Begins to read. He h the look of a man whose privacy has been violated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a suicide note. (to Verrecchia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask me all these questions and you've already read this suicide note? INT. PETER SMITH-KINGSLEY'S APARTMENT. DAY. There's music everywhere - and stands - and posters of performances and PHOTOGRAPHS OF PETER CONDUCTING. Peter i opera repetiteur. Ripley is sitting at Peter's piano, pla from the score of Vivaldi's Stabat Mater. Peter's He's setting the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine, if Dickie did kill Freddie, what must that be like? To wake up every morning, how can you? Just wake up and be a person, drink a coffee...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, however terrible, however hurtful - it all makes sense, doesn't it? inside your head. You never meet anybody who thinks they're a bad person or that they're cruel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're still tormented, you must be, you've killed somebody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you put the past in a room, in the cellar, and lock the door and just never go in there? Because that's what I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably. In my case it's probably a whole building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you meet someone special and all you want to do is toss them the key, say open up, step inside, but you can't because it's dark and there are demons and if anybody saw how ugly it was... Peter's come over, stands behind him over the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the music talking. Harder to be bleak if you're playing Knees up Mother Brown. He vamps this vaudeville song over Ripley's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep wanting to do that - fling open the door - let the light in, clean everything out. If I could get a huge eraser and rub everything out...starting with myself...the thing is, Peter, if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Ripley falls silent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No key, huh? INT. SANTA MARIA DELLA PIETA, BRIDGE OF SIGHS. DAY. A YOUNG BOY SINGS the soprano part of Vivaldi's STABAT MA A piercingly pure sound in Vivaldi's own church.  The orchestra - rehearsing - is conducted by Peter from the organ. Ripley slips in at the back of the church. He stands and listens. Peter sees him, smiles.  Ripley smiles back. EXT. VENICE, S.LUCIA RAILWAY STATION. DAY. MARGE appears on the steps, carrying an overnight bag. Ri and Peter have come to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing him warmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Peter, so good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Marge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom. They walk towards the Vaporetto. MARGE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you found Peter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we sort of found each other. Marge smiles enigmatically. Ripley registers. PETER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Dickie's father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not coming till the morning. Evidently his stomach - I don't think the food here is agreeing with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking forward to seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie hasn't killed himself. I'm sure of that. There's a private detective on the case now - a Mr MacCarron - Dickie's father's employing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a terrific idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's American. He's already discovered Dickie cashed checks for $1000 the day before he disappeared. They step onto the Vaporetto. MARGE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you do before you jump in the Tiber?  I don't think so. EXT. RIPLEY'S HOUSE, VENICE. DAY. The boat arrives at the entrance to the house. Peter open the door as Ripley collects Marge's bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's Tom's. Splendid, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Golly. Who's paying for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter found it for me. I can afford it because it's damp and, and falling down. INT. RIPLEY'S HOUSE, VENICE. DAY. Marge, entering the living room, is astonished at its grandeur. She walks around as Ripley heads for the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is spectacular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why Tom wanted you to stay.  It's better than squeezing into my room, and I know how you hate hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hotel would've been fine. (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to tell Mr Greenleaf how far his dollar has stretched. Ripley is shaking a martini. Marge laughs, helpless, some raging. Peter turns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing. I'm just thinking about when Tom arrived in Mongi. (to Ripley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the manner born. EXT. PIAZZA SAN MARCO, VENICE. DAY. St Mark's Square is buzzing with life - tourists, balloon sellers - a man playing saxophone. HERBERT GREENLEAF sits in the colonade on one of the many tables at Florian's Ca cradling a glass of hot water. He gets up as Marge and Ri arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Greenleaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom. How are you?  You look well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far cry from New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, good morning.  Unusual weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, sir?  Any better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good.  Sticking with hot water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mr MacCarron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Remo. The police are amateurs. Well, my boy, it's come to a pretty pass, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  What's the detective hoping to find in San Remo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's being thorough, that's all. I'm learning about my son, Tom, now he's missing. I'm learning a great deal about him. I hope you can fill in some more blanks for me. Marge has been good enough to do that, about Mongibello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try my best, sir. Obviously I'll do anything to help Dickie. Marge looks at him in contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This theory, the letter he left for you, the Police think that's a clear indication he was planning on doing something...to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't believe that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to, dear. I'd like to talk to Tom alone - perhaps this afternoon? Would you mind? Marge, what a man may say to his sweetheart and what he'll admit to another fellow -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a waste of lives and opportunities and - A saxophonist is blaring away in the piazza. Greenleaf suddenly explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - I'd pay that fellow a hundred dollars right now to shut up! INT. RIPLEY'S HOUSE. AFTERNOON. Herbert Greenleaf sits on a chair, Ripley pours him some

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading, plunging into gloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Marge doesn't know the half of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it might hurt her to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his passport photo? Did you hear? To scratch out your own face like that - can you imagine - the frame of mind you'd have to be in? (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've thought about going to the police but I can't face it. I can't face anything anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel guilty. I feel like I pushed him away. I spoke and he heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (such a disappointed father)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if we all pushed him away what about him pushing us away? You've been a great friend to my son. Everything is someone else's fault. We all want to sow wild oars. Somebody's got to - what's the word? (Ripley shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment someone confronts him he lashes out.  He lashes out. You know, people always say you can't choose your parents, but you can't choose your children. INT. RIPLEY'S HOUSE, VENICE. DUSK. Ripley wakes up from an awful, chilling nightmare, his he full of ghosts. He's cramped up in an armchair, his arms sine foetal protection. HIS DOOR KNOCKER IS BEING REPEATE SHAKEN. He surfaces thickly, stumbles to the door. It's P and Marge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was asleep. I must have fallen asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look ghastly, Tom. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Dickie's Dad go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's having an early night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor man. (she heads to her room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were knocking on that door for ever. (she fiddles inside the sleeve of her dress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've broken my strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fix some drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You walk in Venice! She takes off her shoe, examining her feet for wear and t then disappears into the bedroom. Peter walks over to Rip a little concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hand on his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to stick around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or I could come back. Ripley looks at him. That's never happened. He digs in hi pocket, finds his key, gives it to Peter. Peter smiles. PETER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your key. INT. RIPLEY'S BATHROOM, VENICE. NIGHT. Ripley's in the bath. Marge knocks on his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, I'm in the bath. Won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, I need to talk to you. It's urgent. Ripley, irritated, opens the door, his towel wrapped arou his waist. Marge is white. She's wearing a robe. She's slightly breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found Dickie's rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got Dickie's rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can explain. He can't. His eyes dart. Marge holds up the evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie promised me he would never take off this ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me put on some clothes and then we can talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. I have to tell Mr Greenleaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, calm down, you're being hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He promised me. I swear I'll never take off this ring until the day -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shut up! His towel slips off from his waist. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wet, Marge, I've lost my towel, I'd really like to put my clothes on. So go and pour us both a drink, will you? She goes off obediently, a zombie. He shuts the door. Immediately he starts looking for something, anything, to kill Marge with. He's got a shoe but it feels too light. opens cabinets, drawers - nail scissors, nothing - then picks up his straight razor and considers it in the mirro INT. RIPLEY'S SITTING ROOM, VENICE. NIGHT. Marge is leaving, coat on, as Ripley comes out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge?  Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a creature caught in headlights)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking for a needle and thread. I wasn't snooping. I was looking for a needle and thread to mend my bra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scent you're wearing. I bought it for you, not Dickie. The thing about Dickie. So many things. The day he was late back from Rome - I tried to tell you this - he was with another girl. I'm not talking about Meredith, another girl we met in a bar. He couldn't be faithful for five minutes. So when he makes a promise it doesn't mean what it means when you make a promise. Or I do. He has so many realities, Dickie, and he believes them all. He lies. He lies, that's his... half the time he doesn't even realize. A SMALL RED STAIN is appearing on the pocket of his robe. he speaks the stain spreads. He looks at it absently. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, for the first time, I've even wondered whether he might have killed Freddie. He would get so crazy if anybody contradicted him - well, you know that. Marge. I loved you - you might as well know - I loved you, and because he knew I loved you, he let you think I loved him. Didn't you see, couldn't you see? I don't know, maybe it's grotesque to say this now, so just write it on a piece of paper or something, and keep it in your purse for a rainy day. Tom loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if she'd heard nothing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have Dickie's rings? His hand goes to his pocket. HE'S GOING TO HAVE TO DO IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. He gave them to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel as if you haven't heard anything I've been saying to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe a single word you've said. Marge is shivering. Ripley, ominous, advances, she retrea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shivering, Marge. Can I hold you? Would you let me hold you? Marge panics, backed up against the door. She screams and turns straight into the arms of a startled PETER who's co back to visit Ripley, and is unlocking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing uncontrollably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Peter! Get me out of here. Ripley storms off. His hand comes out of his pocket COVER IN BLOOD from the razor. Peter notices, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You try. You try talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls after him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom. Tom! Tell me, what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not turning around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give up. INT. RIPLEY HOUSE, LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Peter has just put a band-aid over Ripley's cut hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be angry with her.  She's upset and needs someone to blame. So she blames you.  I'll go home and talk to her.  As for you - either get a safety razor or grow a beard. INT. LOBBY, EUROPA REGINA HOTEL, VENICE. MORNING. Ripley hurries through the gleaming marble entrance. INT. HERBERT GREENLEAF'S SUITE, EUROPA REGINA. DAY. Ripley knocks on the door. It's opened by a face he doesn recognize. A middle-aged heavy set man. It's MacCARRON, t private investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mr Greenleaf here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ripley? I'm Alvin MacCarron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I don't know, I just know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, there's female intuition, and then there are facts - Greenleaf sits with a scrubbed Marge, her hair pulled bac as if newly-widowed. THE RINGS SIT GLINTING ON THE COFFEE TABLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir. (smiles thinly at Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge, you should have waited, didn't Peter tell you I'd come by and pick you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marge has been telling us about the rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I feel ridiculous I didn't mention them yesterday - I clean forgot - ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you didn't mention them because there's only one conclusion to be drawn. Ripley worries about what that conclusion is as Mr Greenl heads into his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to take Marge for a little walk, Tom.  Mr MacCarron wants to talk with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling caged in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go down to the bar - no need for you to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he should talk to you alone. He helps Marge to her feet and leads her out. RIPLEY IS PARALYSED. He waits for the door to shut. Aimlessly he wa out onto the terrace, with its staggering, beautiful and indifferent view. EXT. EUROPA REGINA, THE GREENLEAF TERRACE. DAY. Ripley stands, steels himself for MacCarron's charges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could probably see my bedroom from here. I can see my house. When you see where you live from a distance it's like a dream, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care for B.S. I don't care to hear it. I don't care to speak it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think Dickie's father sent him to Europe in the first place? Did you know at Princeton Dickie Greenleaf half- killed a boy? Ripley turns, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a party. Over some girl. He kicked the kid several times in the head. Put him in the hospital. The boy had a wire fixed in his jaw. The Rome Police didn't think to ask Mr Greenleaf. MacCarron gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor did they think to check whether a Thomas Ripley had ever been a student at Princeton University. I turned up a Tom Ripley who'd been a piano tuner in the music department. Ripley's head drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See - in America we're taught to check a fact before it becomes a fact. We're taught to nose around when a girl drowns herself, find out if that girl was pregnant, find out if Dickie had an embarrassment there. Ripley doesn't know where this barrage is going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Greenleaf appreciates your loyalty. He really does. Marge, she's got a hundred theories, but there are a few things she doesn't know. We hope she never knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope she never knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three different people saw Dickie get into Freddie Miles' car. A man who won't identify himself because he was jumping someone else's wife at the time saw Dickie removing license plates from a red sports car. The Police know about this man because he happens to be a Policeman. He walks out of the room, returns carrying THE LICENSE PL from Freddie's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found these in the basement of Dickie's apartment. They belonged to Freddie's car. Mr Greenleaf has asked me to lose them in the canal this evening. Ripley can't believe what he's hearing. It's like a dream

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Greenleaf also feels there was a silent promise in Dickie's letter to you which he intends to honor. He intends to transfer a good part of Dickie's income from his trust into your name. He doesn't intend to give the Italian police any information about Dickie's past. He's rather hoping you'll feel the same. There is a silence in which this strange compact is agree EXT. EUROPA REGINA MOORING. DAY. Ripley stands with Marge, Mr Greenleaf and MacCarron at t water's edge - MOTOR LAUNCH growling. They shake hands, a then MacCarron and Mr Greenleaf get into the launch. Herb Greenleaf carries the saxophone case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel I never should have said those things to you the other evening. I was pretty flustered, the rings and - and you looked so, I don't know. Marge shakes her head to silence him. RIPLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I hope that note goes to New York in your purse, for a rainy day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Peter has a concert in Athens next month - and he's asked if I want to go along, help out. He says goodbye by the way - he's in rehearsal, otherwise -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I think there's never been a Ripley rainy day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lunging at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was you - I know it was you, Tom. I know it was you. I know you killed Dickie. I know it was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Marge. He puts his hand out to control her. She pushes it away. STARTS TO LASH OUT AT HIM, the frustration too much, so t Ripley has to cover his face. MacCarron comes off the boa restrain her. Ripley looks at him as if to say: what do, she's hysterical. MacCarron nods, pulls her on to boat. Greenleaf catches Ripley's eye, guiltily. Turns awa They stand silhouetted as the launch revs up and surges o towards open waters, passing the little fleets of gondola EXT. FERRY FOR ATHENS, NAPLES. DAY. A week later and Peter and Ripley are on the deck of the ferry, the HELLENES, as it sails towards Greece. They're laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask me what I want to change about this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to change about this moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. INT. PETER'S CABIN. DUSK. Peter's in a bathrobe organising his currency, his traveller's cheques. Ripley knocks on the door, comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  What are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kinds of things. Making plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plans - good, plans for tonight or plans for the future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Both. My plan right now is to go up on deck, look at the sunset. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go. I don't want to get dressed yet. Come back though.  Come back. (smiles at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you look so relaxed, like a completely different person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's entirely your fault.  And, if I fall overboard, that'll be your fault too. EXT. DECK OF THE HELLENES. SUNSET. Ripley stands on deck, staring at the magnificent sunset. Then a voice shakes him from his reverie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie?  Dickie? He turns. He's caught. Suddenly he's Dickie. MEREDITH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie, my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Meredith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking at you, your clothes, I wouldn't have known you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've spotted me and so you get the reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding. Are you alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly. I couldn't be less alone. Meredith points to the UPPER DECK BALCONY where TWO OLDER COUPLES are walking around the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  Aunt Joan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And co. A lot of co. Oh, God, I've thought about you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've thought about you. And now he's thinking I can't kill them all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I thought about you I was mostly hating you. Where've you been hiding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been hiding. I've been in Police custody. They've been trying to flush out Freddie's killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're letting me have this vacation. Which is why the get-up. Which is why you haven't heard from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the whole world thinks you killed Freddie? It's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Look, I can't talk now. Later. Later? He kisses her.  Full of future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - are you travelling under R?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what - I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie, are you with Peter Smith- Kingsley?  I bet you are. My aunt thought she saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Smith-Kingsley? I haven't seen him in months.  No, I'm alone. (and he understands this is not any kind of lie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's working on his score, lying on his front, apparen engrossed. Ripley knocks and enters. Looks long at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. But I think we should stay in here for the rest of the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that Meredith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was who Meredith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith Logue. You were kissing somebody. Looked like Meredith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly kissing. Kissing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't look that way - you know - from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied. To her. She thought she'd seen you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dickie and Peter, that's just too good gossip, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Tom and Peter even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that would be even better gossip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, why? (completely lost)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm completely lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm lost, too. I'm going to be stuck in the basement, aren't I, that's my, that's my - terrible and alone and dark - and I've lied about who I am, and where I am, and so nobody can ever find me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean lied about who you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I always thought - better to be a fake somebody than a real nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about - you're not a nobody! That's the last thing you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't forget. I have the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the key. Tell me some good things about Tom Ripley. Don't get up. Just tell me some nice things. He sits on the bed, leans against Peter. His eyes are brimming with tears.  He takes the cord from Peter's robe begins twisting it in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good things about Tom Ripley?  Could take some time!... Tom is talented. Tom is tender... Tom is beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (during this, and tender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a liar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tom is a mystery... Ripley is pressing against him, moving up his body, kisse his shoulder, the cord wrapped tight in his hands... INT. RIPLEY'S CABIN. NIGHT. Ripley returns to his cabin. Sits on the bed, desolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: <i>...Tom is not a nobody. Tom has secrets he doesn't want to tell me, and I wish he would. Tom has nightmares. That's not a good thing. Tom has someone to love him. That is a good thing! (feeling Ripley's weight on him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is crushing me. Tom is crushing me. (suddenly alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, you're crushing me! The door of his closet flips open with the swell and he catches his reflection. It swings shut. Open then shut. Through the porthole the weather's changing as the light dies. There's a swell as the horizon rises and falls in t round glass. Ripley, alone, in a nightmare of his own mak THE END. Lullaby for Cain From the silence from the night comes a distant lullabye Cry, remembering that first cry Your brother standing by and loved both loved beloved sons of mine sing a lullabye mother is close by innocent eyes such innocent eyes Envy stole your brother's life came home murdered peace of mind left you nightmares on the pillow sleep now Soul, surrendering your soul the heart of you not whole for love but love what toll Cast into the dark branded with the mark of shame of Cain From the garden of God's light to a wilderness of light sleep now sleep now.
